title: A Newburyport teen’s body was unidentified for 33 years. Now, his aunt and a cold-case aficionado want to bring him home.
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: Anthony Angelli Rea's remains, unidentified for 33 years, were identified through genome sequencing as missing Newburyport teen from 1988.
Rea's aunt, Carolann Angelli, and Maya Ambrose set up a GoFundMe to repatriate his remains for burial with family.
The Harbor School, from which Rea disappeared, closed in 2012 amid allegations of mismanagement and declining enrollment.

title: Did you follow the local news this week? Take our Greater Boston news quiz.
author: Peter Chianca
bullets: Boston.com released a quiz covering news about Hasbro, Aroldis Chapman, Arthur T. Demoulas, Matt Damon, and Ben Affleck.
The quiz invites readers to test their knowledge of recent stories in Greater Boston, featuring trending local news.
Boston.com's general assignment editor, Peter Chianca, contributed to the quiz, incorporating AI in question formulation.

title: Amid opt-out rumors, Sam Kennedy says Alex Bregman ‘wants to be here’ with Red Sox
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Alex Bregman could opt out of his Red Sox contract at season's end for potential free agency.
Red Sox President Sam Kennedy said both the team and Bregman want him to remain in Boston.
Despite rumors, Bregman focuses on winning games and defers contract talks until the offseason.

title: Bill Belichick says in new book that Tom Brady made ‘right decision’ to leave Patriots in 2020
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Bill Belichick stated in a new book that Tom Brady made the right decision to leave the Patriots in 2020.
Belichick described the Patriots' situation as 'impossible' for Brady, citing financial constraints and need for a team rebuild.
Brady led his new team, the Buccaneers, to a Super Bowl win in his first season after leaving the Patriots.

title: West Boylston town administrator fired after Trump flag dispute sues town
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: James Ryan, former West Boylston town administrator, sues the town for $1.3 million over alleged wrongful termination.
Ryan was dismissed after a conflict with Police Chief Dennis Minnich over a Trump flag in a police gym.
The lawsuit claims Ryan's firing was retaliation for enforcing ethics laws restricting political signs on public property.

title: 18-year-old injured in R.I. after lighting himself on fire for TikTok challenge
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: An 18-year-old in North Smithfield, R.I. suffered severe burns attempting a TikTok challenge involving fire and water.
The challenge involved pouring gasoline and lighting themselves on fire before jumping into Slatersville Reservoir.
Victim was hospitalized with second- and third-degree burns; his 16-year-old companion was unharmed.

title: ‘Fear and uncertainty’: Everett officials cancel Hispanic Heritage Month festival amid ICE crackdown
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Everett cancels Fiesta Del Rio amid increased ICE activity causing community fear.
Festival was to celebrate Hispanic Heritage Month on September 20 at Rivergreen Park.
Mayor DeMaria cited community safety concerns for the cancellation of the cultural event.

title: Josh Kraft ends mayoral campaign after coming in second by nearly 50 points in Tuesday’s preliminary
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Josh Kraft ends his campaign after losing to Mayor Michelle Wu by nearly 50 points in Boston's preliminary election.
Kraft contributed $5.5 million to his campaign and focused on housing affordability and homelessness during his bid.
He plans to donate $3 million to address humanitarian issues in Boston despite suspending his mayoral candidacy.

title: Josh McDaniels defends Drake Maye: ‘He’s the right guy’ for Patriots
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Josh McDaniels defends Patriots QB Drake Maye amid criticism following Week 1 loss to the Raiders.
Maye struggled in the second half, raising concerns about his adaptation to McDaniels' complex offensive system.
Patriots aim to support Maye by emphasizing the run game, planning adjustments for Week 2 against the Dolphins.

title: Authorities in a Connecticut town want to speak with whoever is painting the squirrels
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: Two squirrels were painted red and blue in East Hartford, Connecticut, near Naubuc Avenue and High Street.
East Hartford Animal Control states the squirrels appear unharmed and are consulting a wildlife rehabilitator to aid them.
Officials request information about the incident via a hotline at 860-291-7572.
